importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The GPEI will face a 30% budget reduction starting in 2026, impacting the feasibility and scope of polio eradication activities.
The $1.7 billion funding gap is projected through 2029, marking a critical period for sustained global polio eradication efforts.
Polio cases have declined since 2024, indicating a positive trend that may be at risk due to funding shortfalls.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This period represents the projected duration of the $1.7 billion funding gap, during which polio eradication efforts may be significantly constrained without new funding.

keyTakeAways: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) faces a $1.7 billion funding shortfall through 2029, primarily due to reduced foreign aid, especially from the United States.

The World Health Organization (WHO) and the Gates Foundation are key stakeholders in the GPEI, with WHO’s director Jamal Ahmed highlighting the risk of critical activities being cut due to funding reductions.
The United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom have reduced their contributions, contributing to the overall funding gap and increasing challenges in maintaining polio eradication programs.
The GPEI plans to focus on high-risk areas—particularly Afghanistan and Pakistan—while scaling back operations in low-risk regions unless outbreaks occur.
To stretch vaccine supplies, the initiative will adopt fractional dosing, using as little as a fifth of a standard vaccine dose without compromising protection.

The persistence of wild polio in Afghanistan and Pakistan (36 cases in 2025) and vaccine-derived polio in 149 cases across countries including Nigeria, underscores the ongoing threat of polio transmission.
Asymptomatic infections and viral shedding in vaccinated individuals can lead to vaccine-derived polio, making surveillance and vaccination critical components of eradication.
Despite progress since 2024, funding shortfalls threaten the long-term viability of polio eradication efforts, emphasizing the need for sustained global cooperation and investment.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The GPEI is central to the article as it is directly affected by the funding shortfall and is implementing strategic changes to continue eradication efforts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI), led by the World Health Organization and including major donors like the Gates Foundation, is facing a $1.7 billion funding shortfall through 2029 due to reduced foreign aid—particularly from the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom. This shortfall threatens to cut critical polio eradication activities, especially in high-risk areas like Afghanistan and Pakistan, where 36 wild polio cases were reported in 2025. To respond, the GPEI will shift focus to high-risk zones, adopt fractional dosing to conserve vaccine supplies, and strengthen collaboration with other health programs like measles vaccination. While wild and vaccine-derived polio cases have declined since 2024, continued funding and global cooperation remain essential to prevent a reversal of progress and achieve the goal of global polio eradication.
title: WHO warns $1.7bn funding shortfall threatens polio eradication efforts
